column1: Setup I18n integration with nuxt-I18n and Crowdin
column26:
See documented decision for I18n. [https://anddigitaltransformation.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/EH/pages/4744020011/ADR+Content+Management+and+Translation+Strategy|https://anddigitaltransformation.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/EH/pages/4744020011/ADR+Content+Management+and+Translation+Strategy|smart-link] 

This ticket is to setup this integration so we can hit the ground running
column319:
14/May/24 6:48 AM;6347d090cafc998a91cfa8a8;[~accountid:60abd889411c22006827c085] 

As mentioned yesterday we have a decision to make for the implementation of this ticket. 

*Our custom router solution for domain/subdomain*

We are working with a custom router solution to be able to divide pages in subdomain and custom domain. Due to this, we have a folder structure which i18n uses to build it’s routes upon. 

The decision we have to make is as follows: 

* *Using the prefix strategy* (this will add “/nl” or “/en” based on the localisation to the URL
** We can use custom pages logic to prevent i18n to create it’s routes including root-domain and sub-domain folders. This gives us greater control over the url’s, and it’s a best practice for SEO and localisation instead of using cookies: [https://veracontent.com/mix/localization-seo-multilingual-websites/|https://veracontent.com/mix/localization-seo-multilingual-websites/|smart-link] 
** Using this strategy, the subdomains for login will also be affected, causing the url’s to become: [http://localhost:3000/login.localhost:3000/|http://localhost:3000/login.localhost:3000/]
* *Using the no_prefix strategy* (localisation will not be visible through URL, only through a cookie)
** The URL will remain [http://localhost:3000/|http://localhost:3000/] and there is no visible indication of the current locale being used (except for a locale switcher that we have to built ). This is stored in a cookie. This is however bad practice for SEO.
** Now we are not pre-fixing our URL’s, we can add configuration to translate our sub-domains. Now [http://login.localhost:3000/|http://login.localhost:3000/] and [http://inloggen.localhost:3000/|http://inloggen.localhost:3000/] are dedicated to the EN and NL locale of the sub-domain.

The plugin offers a few more strategies, but they are all using the prefix strategy (they are just excluding the default locale etc). Thats why I just focussed on those 2 for now.
column320:
14/May/24 8:05 AM;60abd889411c22006827c085;So the [http://localhost:3000/login.localhost:3000/|http://localhost:3000/login.localhost:3000/] issue is something with our custom routing logic that needs to be fixed as its also happening with NuxtLink. Ive created a bug for this.

So if we rule that out, my Product head goes to the SEO part and what KPN would want. And I think they are probably obsessed by SEO, and thus I would think adding the prefix might be the way to go. But would value [~accountid:61bafd21755091006a276b65] 's thoughts before making the final decision

column1: SPIKE: Determine best course of action for Contentful localisation vs integration of Vue I18n to the project
column26:
* All content should be coming from Contentful (product descriptions, product images, product categories and attributes (e.g., size, brand), marketing content)
* All sensitive information should be coming from our Postgres (product prices, inventory levels, product variants, order history). 
* Content coming from Contentful has a feature that allows us to fetch data based on locale. This requires manual translation of content. 
* Should we want to automate this process, Crowdin is a plugin that provides a free translation service via AI. There are others (Phrase, Localise, etc) but these only provide a trial for a period of time. 
* In order to use Crowdin with Contentful, you can watch this video: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vsjyz3D1CyA|https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vsjyz3D1CyA|smart-link] 
* Hardcoded content and content coming from the database that need translating, we will use [vue-I18n |https://kazupon.github.io/vue-i18n/]
column319:
25/Apr/24 1:22 PM;60abd889411c22006827c085;* All content should be coming from Contentful (product descriptions, product images, product categories and attributes (e.g., size, brand), marketing content)
* All sensitive information should be coming from our Postgres (product prices, inventory levels, product variants, order history). 
* Content coming from Contentful has a feature that allows us to fetch data based on locale. This requires manual translation of content. 
* Should we want to automate this process, Crowdin is a plugin that provides a free translation service via AI. There are others (Phrase, Localise, etc) but these only provide a trial for a period of time. 
* In order to use Crowdin with Contentful, you can watch this video: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vsjyz3D1CyA|https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vsjyz3D1CyA|smart-link] 
* Hardcoded content and content coming from the database that need translating, we will use [vue-I18n |https://kazupon.github.io/vue-i18n/]

Next steps: 

* Create ticket to set up Contentful locales
* Create ticket to set up Crowdin integration
* Create ticket to set up vue-I18n integration
column320:
25/Apr/24 1:51 PM;60ac10b81155bb006fbd90e3;I agree with the proposed tools for the localisation. It’s worth noting that even though Crowdin would streamline the process, the translations still need human quality reviews. 
We should also keep an eye on how the localised content affects performance. Great work!

column1: Add facebook log ins to create account step
column26:
*STORY*

As a prospective KPN customer, I want to use a facebook in when creating my KPN account so I can have increased account security. 

*BACKGROUND*

A larger percentage of users are leaning on social media log ins to increase the convenience of centralised passwords, and improved account security. Google login accounted for 73% of social logins and 73% of monthly active social login users.

A longer form articles about this subject can be found [here|https://kinde.com/guides/authentication/types-and-methods/social-logins/#:~:text=According%20to%20LoginRadius%20close%20to,year%2Dolds%20prefer%20social%20login.]. 

*SCOPE SUMMARY*

In Scope

* Adding a facebook log in option to the create account step 

Out of Scope

* Adding any other social media log ins to this step 

*UX/UI DESIGN*

* [+Figma Board+|https://www.figma.com/file/GUtpArHRsWfoSgpPVEQReI/KPN-Group-Practice-Sprint-Screenshots?type=whiteboard&node-id=0%3A1&t=ildQjMVwVsWyoDFv-1]

*TECH DESIGN*

* [+Previously completed Vercel App+ |https://kpn-spike.vercel.app/]

*DEPENDENCIES*

TBC

*QUESTIONS*

TBC

*ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA*

Given a user selects “create account”, they’re redirected to the appropriate screen and:

* The steps on [this story|https://anddigitaltransformation.atlassian.net/browse/ENKPS-4] have been completed
* An optional facebook log in is presented on this screen
The full flow is detailed on the Figma, but if you look at the screenshot below, its the account confirmation section that we’re creating here.

After the user has confirmed their account as part of the account creation flow, they will be sent the account created email. The PDF is attached. 

* This is the only time we can see this type of email notification used
* It contains a similar structure as the confirm account email in terms of header, button and content
* This email is more of an FYI and has no action required off of it

column1: New user | Mobile phone page overview
column26:
As a prospective KPN customer, I want to purchase a mobile phone online so that I can have it delivered to me. 

*BACKGROUND*

While KPN is catering to users that prefer to purchase in store, they’re also catering to users that prefer to purchase online. The main reason for online purchases are the convenience of it. You can have a new phone at your door in only a few clicks. 

*SCOPE SUMMARY*

In Scope

* Assembling the structure of this page
* Placeholder components for the cards
* Grid Layout of the page 

Out of Scope

* Filters 
* Details of the card 
* Navigation
* Footer

*UX/UI DESIGN*

Figma screenshots can be found [here|https://www.figma.com/file/GUtpArHRsWfoSgpPVEQReI/KPN-Group-Practice-Sprint-Screenshots?type=whiteboard&node-id=0-1&t=6d57GLTcQzHRTvAt-0]. 

*TECH DESIGN*

TBC

*DEPENDENCIES*

TBC

*QUESTIONS*

* The logo icons of the phone brands seem to be quick filters. Should be experiment with removing this, since they already have filters? It feels like a duplication?
* Instead of endless scrolling, should be not implement the “see more” button to expand the grid?
* Do we want to include the special header image in this overview, or create a seperate ticket?

*ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA*

Given a user is using selects, mobile phones from the home page, then:

* They’re presented with an overview of available mobile phones for purchase
* The can view the “special” header image 
* They can view the filters (placeholder?)

column1: SPIKE: Compare Twillio and Supabase for email notifications

03/May/24 1:48 PM;60abd889411c22006827c085;* Supabase offers 3 emails an hour with their built-in SMTP server. This may not be enough for us, so I would suggest using Supabase with a custom SMTP provider that you can integrate with Supabase’s Authentication service. SendGrid comes recommended by Supabase and you can follow the instructions here to setup. 
* This provides 100 emails/day on a free tier account which should be enough
* [https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/auth-smtp|https://supabase.com/docs/guides/auth/auth-smtp|smart-link] 

There is another question though that is yet to be answered. And this revolves around whether we want the BE team to build our own custom SMTP server for email notifications. Keith is thinking about this and will come back to us next week with an answer as this perhaps deviates from the KPN learning agenda, but may be easy and fun for them to implement. 

Next steps: 

* Wait for Keith on BE response
* Add a ticket to backlog named: Integrate Custom SMTP server with Supabase and SendGrid

column1: SPIKE: Research best hosting provider for project
column320:
25/Apr/24 1:40 PM;6294f4fd1a2bdf0070942111;According to [Vercel’s pricing page|https://vercel.com/pricing], its free plan does not support adding team members. 

!Screenshot 2024-04-16 at 11.21.00.png|width=83.33333333333334%,alt="Screenshot 2024-04-16 at 11.21.00.png"!

There is a workaround for non Vercel members to trigger a deploy using specific[ github actions|https://github.com/marketplace/actions/vercel-action]. In this way only the repository owner needs to be a Vercel member, the rest can be linked through github. If any commits are made to the repo, Vercel will auto-deploy, regardless who committed. Please note: the non-vercel git users wont have access to full deployment information (server console etc), just the general status which gets posted to the github deployment list inside the repo.


----


A similar situation applies for Netlify. [https://www.netlify.com/pricing/|https://www.netlify.com/pricing/|smart-link] 

!Screenshot 2024-04-16 at 11.23.37.png|width=83.33333333333334%,alt="Screenshot 2024-04-16 at 11.23.37.png"!

The free plan allows only 1 member with unlimited git contributors. You can read more [here|https://docs.netlify.com/accounts-and-billing/team-management/roles-and-permissions/#roles-and-permissions] about the different roles and permissions. Git contributors are able to trigger builds and deploys from git repo’s, but are not able to edit settings, configs, etc.

FINAL VERDICT:
Both services require similar workarounds for teams looking to use the free plans. It’s up to the team to decide which service they’re most familiar with or have a preference for.
column321: 26/Apr/24 8:54 AM;60abd889411c22006827c085;Thanks Nneka, This is great research. So we need to make 2 decisions: Vercel/Netlify? & CD or not? 🙂. No CD means only one person can deploy, which I don’t like. So perhaps CD is the way forward…

column1: SPIKE: Research best way of fetching content from contentful: Contentful Client vs GraphQL
column320:
23/Apr/24 9:30 AM;633409fea84c7f79c38738eb;For This Spike two different tools were analysed using the Contentful documentation and previous project experiences. 

Here there is a comparison of the benefits of both api’s 

# *GraphQL Contentful API*:
#* *Advantages*:
#** GraphQL offers more flexibility and control over the data you retrieve (via queries). You can specify exactly which fields you need for a query, reducing  the data over fetching.
#** GraphQL enables you to retrieve nested and related data in a single request, which can lead to fewer network requests compared to RESTful APIs.
#** GraphQL provides a strongly typed schema.
# *Contentful Client API*:
#* *Advantages*:
#** Simple to use: The Contentful Client API provides a straightforward way to fetch content from Contentful using RESTful endpoints.
#** Less complexity: The Contentful Client API abstracts away some of the complexity of data fetching, making it easier to get started.

Altought the Contenful client is easy to use by setting us some environment keys it has some limitations that will generate performance issues in the long run. 


{noformat}const contentful = require('contentful')

const client = contentful.createClient({
  space: '<space_id>',
  accessToken: '<content_delivery_api_key>'
})

client.getAsset('<asset_id>')
.then((asset) => console.log(asset))
.catch(console.error){noformat}

Just by implementing this code, we can retrieve a specific asset. However, a drawback arises when we lack control over the returned data, as the REST API would provide a JSON response that necessitates transformation to extract the desired information. These transformations often lead to decreased performance, particularly during initialization or invocation.

Given this challenge, I recommend opting for the GraphQL API, which grants us comprehensive control over the fields and schema components returned in our components or pages. By specifying the exact fields we require in our queries, we avoid costly data transformations. Additionally, utilizing GraphQL allows us to consolidate all necessary data elements into a single API call, offering greater efficiency compared to the Client API, which may require multiple calls to fulfill the same request. Furthermore, configuring the environment for GraphQL is straightforward.



{noformat}curl -g \
-X POST \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer {TOKEN}" \
-d  '{"query":"query($preview:Boolean){blogCollection(preview:$preview){items{title}}}","variables":{"preview":true}}' \
https://graphql.contentful.com/content/v1/spaces/{SPACE}/environments/{ENVIRONMENT}{noformat}



Example query: 



{noformat}query($preview: Boolean){
  blogCollection(preview: $preview){
    items{
      title
    }
  }
}{noformat}



*Conclusion:*  The GraphQL api can generate great value in our KPN project reducing data transformation, re-fetching and will help us to be more performant in the front-end.

column1: Create content model for log in
column26:
*BACKGROUND*

KPN would like to move over to Contentful. As part of this move, we need to include content modelling in our development. 

*SCOPE SUMMARY*

In Scope

* Heading 
* Email address field 
* Password field 
* Ts and cs checkbox 
* CTA Button 

Out of Scope

* TBC

TBC

*QUESTIONS*

* This is exactly the same list as we have for account creation, so do we need a content model for log in?

column1: Add google option to log in step
column26:
*STORY*

As a KPN customer, I want to log into my account so I can access my data. 

*BACKGROUND*

A larger percentage of users are leaning on social media log ins to increase the convenience of centralised passwords, and improved account security. Google login accounted for 73% of social logins and 73% of monthly active social login users.

A longer form articles about this subject can be found [here|https://kinde.com/guides/authentication/types-and-methods/social-logins/#:~:text=According%20to%20LoginRadius%20close%20to,year%2Dolds%20prefer%20social%20login.]. 

*SCOPE SUMMARY*

In Scope

* Adding a google log in option to the log in step. 

Out of Scope

* Adding any other social media log ins to this step 

*UX/UI DESIGN*

* [+Figma Board+|https://www.figma.com/file/GUtpArHRsWfoSgpPVEQReI/KPN-Group-Practice-Sprint-Screenshots?type=whiteboard&node-id=0%3A1&t=ildQjMVwVsWyoDFv-1]

*TECH DESIGN*

* [+Previously completed Vercel App+ |https://kpn-spike.vercel.app/]

*DEPENDENCIES*

TBC

*QUESTIONS*

TBC

*ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA*

Given a user selects “create account”, they’re redirected to the appropriate screen and:

* The steps on [this story|https://anddigitaltransformation.atlassian.net/browse/ENKPS-3] have been completed
* An optional Google log in is presented on this screen

column1: SPIKE: Create content model for account creation
column26:
KPN would like to move over to Contentful. As part of this move, we need to include content modelling in our development. The purpose of this spike is to brainstorm how we want to approach content modelling in general, but also more specifically for the account creation step. 

Some ideas below. 

*SCOPE SUMMARY*

In Scope

* Heading 
* Email address field 
* Password field
* CTA Button 

*Other*

* Will we allow the content editor to make changes to the email and password fields? No
* Will we allow the content editor to remove the button? No - but they can change the text

*STORY*

As a KPN customer, I want to log into my account so I can access my data. 

*BACKGROUND*

KPN would like to incentivise users to manage their accounts digitally without the need for customer support intervention. 

*SCOPE SUMMARY*

In Scope

* Creating a log in page 
* Linking this page to the log in link on the home page 

Out of Scope

* Creating the KPN dashboard
* Completing create account 
* Social media log ins 
* Linking to any other home page items 

*UX/UI DESIGN*

* [+Figma Board+|https://www.figma.com/file/GUtpArHRsWfoSgpPVEQReI/KPN-Group-Practice-Sprint-Screenshots?type=whiteboard&node-id=0%3A1&t=ildQjMVwVsWyoDFv-1]

*TECH DESIGN*

* [+Previously completed Vercel App+ |https://kpn-spike.vercel.app/]

*DEPENDENCIES*

TBC

*QUESTIONS*

TBC

*ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA*

Given a user selects “log in”, they’re redirected to the appropriate screen and:

* They’re presented with the log in page
* They can view the email address and password field 
** Both fields are required 
* They can view the log in button 
* Selecting the log in button will redirect the user to the KPN dashboard 
* Under the create button you will find the clickable create account prompt

*STORY*

As a prospective KPN customer, I want to create an account so that I can complete my online purchase. 

*BACKGROUND*

As a new customer, KPN customers will be required to create their account, but as an existing customer, they’re incentivised to use their dashboard to manage their account. Some of the benefits for creating an account for an e-commerce product include:

* Increase conversion and engagement rates 
* Collect user data
* Improve user experience

Additionally, we want to seperate the account creation and log in steps (in line with the user selection), as this will:

* Reduce confusion and frustration 
* Improve conversion

A [longer form|https://app.uxcel.com/courses/common-patterns/loginsignup-best-practices-854] article is available here for the thinking behind decision. 

*SCOPE SUMMARY*

In Scope

* Completing the account creation page 
* Linking this page to the create account link on the home page 

Out of Scope

* Creating the KPN dashboard
* Completing log in 
* Social media log ins 
* Linking to any other home page items 

*UX/UI DESIGN*

* [+Figma Board+|https://www.figma.com/file/GUtpArHRsWfoSgpPVEQReI/KPN-Group-Practice-Sprint-Screenshots?type=whiteboard&node-id=0%3A1&t=ildQjMVwVsWyoDFv-1]

*TECH DESIGN*

* [+Previously completed Vercel App+ |https://kpn-spike.vercel.app/]

*DEPENDENCIES*

TBC

*QUESTIONS*

*STORY*

* As a [user role], - we should also indicate if its global or country customised
* I want to [action],
* so that [outcome].

*BACKGROUND*

Business context / Problem statement

* Bulletized rationale and problem statement for the ticket. What is the thing youre trying to solve with this ticket?
* Think of this as the why.

* Notes from the PO for the devs to keep in mind.

*SCOPE SUMMARY*

In Scope

* Details on what is in scope

Out of Scope

* Details on where the scope ends, for example if you want certain systems to be left out of consideration.

*UX/UI DESIGN*

Product design details can go here. If simple, can insert screen mockups, icons, visuals here in the story. If necessary, can reference a separate design ticket.

*TECH DESIGN*

Technical design and specs can be documented here. Can reference an external link (Confluence), if necessary.

*DEPENDENCIES*

What information, data, systems…are required to develop this ticket

*QUESTIONS*

Space to add questions during refinement that need to be answered to detail the ticket

*ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA*

Given a user is using [the product or feature] then ...

* Detailed bullets of what the end result of this tickets needs to do
* Imagine this to be a checklist for the developer, when they can check all of this they will put this story on done, describe from a functional level (the what), instead of instructions for developers on how.
